isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - ENGINE COOLING SYSTEM - OPERATION - CONTINUOUS DEAERATION SYSTEM

svcprocinfo.para: When the cooling system is filled through the pressure cap fill tube, coolant enters the main cooling system through the make-up line, from the deaeration (surge) tank to the suction side of the water pump. Coolant then fills the radiator core and engine from the bottom upward, forcing air out the vent tubes. The vent tubes connect from the radiator core and the engine side of the thermostat housing to ports located above the coolant level in the tank.

When the engine is running, there is a continuous small flow of coolant through the engine vent hose. Once the thermostat opens, there is also a small flow through the radiator vent hose. Any air in the coolant will separate when it reaches the reservoir and will eventually exit through the pressure cap.

caution.para: If the coolant should get extremely low and the engine gets very hot, let the engine cool for approximately 15 minutes before adding coolant. Then add coolant with the engine running. Adding cold coolant to a hot engine can crack the cylinder head or crankcase.

warning.para: Allow the engine to cool down before removing the pressure cap from the deaeration tank. ALWAYS INSULATE the cap by wrapping it with a thick, heavy cloth.

To prevent possible injury from scalding water or steam, DO NOT pull the pressure cap off immediately when it has been loosened to the first "notch." Pause momentarily to allow time for excess pressure to release through the overflow tube.

step1.para: Push the pressure cap down, then slowly turn it counter-clockwise to loosen it to the first "notch" position. PAUSE to observe the WARNING.
Continue to push down and turn the pressure cap counter-clockwise, then remove it. Keep your face away from cap opening.
